awd_titl_txt: Thirty-First Cumberland Conference on Combinatorics, Graph Theory and Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
The 31st Cumberland Conference on Combinatorics, Graph Theory and Computing will be held  May 18-19, 2019 at the University of Central Florida in Orlando, Florida. This is the latest in a series of conferences, usually held annually, that provide a venue for students and researchers, particularly but not exclusively from the southeastern United States, to discuss the latest advances in discrete mathematics and computer science.  Discrete mathematics is a rapidly expanding field with applications in communication, network and information science, life sciences and engineering.  The conference will promote applications of discrete mathematics in computer science and encourage participation by students and groups underrepresented in mathematics.  It provides a setting where researchers at all levels can present their work, exchange information and collaborate on solving problems.  It strengthens the regional network of researchers while connecting that network to broader national and international communities.

The conference scope includes all areas of discrete mathematics.  Four featured internationally-known speakers will give 50-minute plenary presentations.  Estimated attendance is around 120 participants, and about 70 contributed 20-minute talks are planned.  There will be a special focus on structural graph theory, supported by two of the plenary speakers and a special session for contributed talks.  Abstracts from the conference will be available indefinitely through a conference abstracts service.  Funding from this award will support travel, accommodation and meal expenses for the featured speaker from outside of US, and other participants identified through a selection process.  The selection process will prioritize women, members of underrepresented minorities, people with disabilities, early-career mathematicians, and researchers without federal funding.

The conference has its own website  https://sciences.ucf.edu/math/cumberland2018/ (to be updated).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The Thirty-First Cumberland Conference on Combinatorics, Graph Theory and Computing, took place at the University of Central Florida  in Orlando, Florida, on Saturday, May 18 and Sunday, May 19, 2019.    The conference location was  the Business Administration Building I (BA1) of  the University of Central Florida. The Scientific Committee members were Mark Ellingham and Robin Thomas; and local organizers were Zixia Song (the principal investigator  on the grant),   Christian Bosse, Vaidyanathan Sivaraman and Yue Zhao.  

The conference covered a broad range of topics in the general area of combinatorics, graph theory and computing. The 99 participants mostly came from the southeastern United States, but one of the invited speakers was international and there were other participants based in Canada, China and Indonesia. The conference featured four plenary talks given by the following distinguished speakers: 

Maria Chudnovsky, Princeton University, ``Detecting Odd Holes";

Daniel Kral Masaryk University (Czech Republic) and University of WarwickUniversity of Warwick (United Kingdom), ``Extremal Problems Concerning Tournaments";

Paul Seymour, Princeton University, ``Concatenating Bipartite Graphs";

Xingxing Yu, Georgia Institute of Technology, ``Coloring Graphs without Subdivision of K5.


There were also 53 twenty-minute talks (with five additional minutes for questions) by other speakers. (56 talks were scheduled but three funded speakers were unable to attend.) These talks ran in three parallel sessions throughout the conference, except that there were two parallel sessions on Sunday afternoon. The talks covered many different subjects, although there was a particular focus on structural graph theory. The conference seems to have been a definite success and to have achieved its goal of allowing participants to see some of the important new developments in the area.


The National Science Foundation (NSF) funding was used to provide travel support to participants who requested support via an application process. 38 people were supported in this way, including 19 graduate students and five postdoctoral fellows. NSF funding also paid for two  plenary speakers.\medskip
The conference web site may be found at

https://sciences.ucf.edu/math/cumberland/


Before 2022, the ``SCHEDULE OF TALKS" link under the ``PROGRAM & PARTICIPANTS" heading provides an outline of the program, with clickable links to abstracts of talks. Under the ``SPEAKERS" heading,  name, headshot and affiliation of each speaker is listed, with clickable links to abstracts of talks and in some cases the talk slides (submitted by speakers on a voluntary basis). 

Due to the changes made at UCF in the past year, the conference website no longer has clickable link. List of speakers (and slides), and conference program and participants can be found below (unofrtunately files for slides and program have been disabled by UCF):

list of speakers and slides for many of the talks may be found at

https://sciences.ucf.edu/math/cumberland/speakers/


and the conference program and participarts may be found at

https://sciences.ucf.edu/math/cumberland/program/

 


Last Modified: 11/07/2022
Modified by: Zixia Song
